title: temp_website
text: I am currently a Year 1 student studying in Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT), pursuing a degree in Bachelor of Applied Computing (FinTech). Some of my hobbies are playing games and basketball. ```

title: FYP Project
text:
Final Year Project (FYP) Project Title
Exploring Brand Portfolio Strategies and Financial Performance in the Automotive Industry
Project Background
The automotive industry is highly competitive, with major manufacturers adopting different strategies to expand their market presence. One common approach is brand portfolio expansion, where companies acquire or develop multiple brands to target different customer segments.
My Final Year Project focuses on analyzing how these large automotive companies build brand empires and how the number of brands they own relates to their financial performance.
Project Objectives
The key objectives of this project were:
To compare the number of brands owned by major automotive manufacturers
To analyze the relationship between brand ownership and company earnings
To use data visualization to communicate insights clearly and effectively
Data and Visualization
{width=85%}
Figure: Number of brands owned by selected car manufacturers and their EBIT (in billion USD).
The visualization presents two quantitative variables:
A horizontal bar chart showing the number of brands or marques owned by each company
Circular markers indicating Earnings Before Interest and Tax (EBIT) over the period Q2 2021 to Q1 2022
Key Findings
From the visualization and analysis:
Volkswagen Group owns the highest number of brands, indicating an aggressive brand expansion strategy.
Toyota, despite owning fewer brands, achieves one of the highest EBIT values, suggesting strong operational efficiency.
Companies such as Tesla demonstrate that high profitability can be achieved even with a limited number of brands.
These findings suggest that while brand expansion increases market coverage, it does not guarantee higher profitability.
Rationale for Visualization Choice
This visualization was chosen because:
It allows direct comparison between companies
It effectively combines categorical data (companies) and numerical data (brand count and earnings)
The layout makes it easy to identify patterns and outliers
By presenting multiple variables in a single view, the visualization supports data-driven storytelling.
Skills and Learning Outcomes
Through this Final Year Project, I developed and strengthened skills in:
Data analysis and interpretation
Data visualization principles
Critical thinking and business insight generation
Communicating complex information clearly using visuals
This project helped me understand how data visualization can be used not only for presentation, but also as a tool for analytical reasoning.

title: Reflection
text:
Reflection on the Use of GenAI GenAI Tools Used
In this assessment, I used ChatGPT as the primary GenAI tool to assist me in completing the tasks. I chose this tool because it is capable of providing clear explanations, structured guidance, and examples related to Quarto, GitHub Pages, markdown formatting, and data visualization concepts, which are essential for this assignment.
How GenAI Helped Me Complete the Assessment
GenAI supported me throughout different stages of the assessment:
Technical setup: It helped me understand the correct steps to create a GitHub Pages repository, clone it into RStudio, and configure the Quarto project properly. For example, it clarified why the repository name must exactly match my GitHub username and how to fix directory-related errors.
Content structuring: GenAI assisted in drafting structured content for different website pages, such as the Data Visualization page and the Final Year Project page. This helped me organize my ideas more clearly rather than starting from a blank page.
Markdown and formatting: It provided examples of markdown syntax for headings, images, lists, and captions, which improved the presentation and readability of my website.
Reflection guidance: GenAI helped me understand what aspects to reflect on, ensuring that my reflection was relevant to the assessment requirements.
Benefits of Using GenAI
The main benefits of using GenAI include:
Efficiency: It significantly reduced the time needed to troubleshoot technical issues and draft content.
Clarity: Explanations were easy to understand, especially for complex concepts such as YAML configuration and GitHub Pages deployment.
Learning support: Instead of giving final answers only, GenAI helped me understand why certain steps were required, which improved my learning experience.
Challenges and Limitations
Despite its usefulness, there were also challenges:
GenAI responses still require critical thinking. Some suggestions needed to be adjusted to fit the exact assessment rules.
Over-reliance on GenAI could reduce independent problem-solving if not used carefully.
The tool does not fully understand my personal context unless I clearly explain it, so human judgment is still necessary.
Future Use of GenAI in Study and Work
In the future, I believe GenAI tools will be highly beneficial for:
Supporting coding and debugging tasks
Drafting reports and documentation
Brainstorming ideas and improving clarity in technical communication
However, I will continue to use GenAI as a supporting tool rather than a replacement for my own thinking and learning.
Final Thoughts
Overall, the use of GenAI enhanced my productivity and confidence in completing this assessment. When used responsibly, GenAI can be a powerful learning aid that complements human effort and supports applied learning, which aligns well with the learning objectives of this course.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Analysis of Brand Ownership and Financial Performance in Major Automotive Companies
Project Overview
This is my analysis on how large automotive companies build brand empires through the ownership of multiple marques, and how this strategy relates to their financial performance. The project uses quantitative data to explore whether owning more brands necessarily leads to higher earnings.
Data Visualization Used in the Project
{width=85%}
Figure: Number of brands owned by major car manufacturers and their earnings (EBIT).
The visualization above compares:
Number of brands/marques owned by each car manufacturer (bar chart)
Earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) in billion U.S. dollars (circular markers)
What the Visualization Shows
From the visualization, we can observe that:
Volkswagen Group owns the highest number of brands (16), forming the largest brand portfolio among the companies shown.
Toyota, despite owning fewer brands (5), records one of the highest EBIT values, indicating strong profitability.
Some companies with fewer brands, such as Tesla, still achieve significant earnings, suggesting that brand quantity alone does not determine financial success.
This highlights the difference between brand expansion strategies and operational efficiency.
Why This Visualization Was Chosen
This visualization was chosen because:
It effectively compares two quantitative variables: number of brands and earnings
The horizontal bar chart allows easy comparison of brand ownership
The circular markers provide a clear visual cue for financial performance
By combining these elements, the visualization tells a clear business story in a single view.
Insights and Learning Outcomes
Through this project, I learned that:
Data visualization can reveal insights that are not immediately obvious from raw numbers
Owning more brands does not always translate into higher profitability
Strategic focus and operational efficiency play a critical role in business success
This project strengthened my understanding of data-driven analysis, visual storytelling, and how visualization can support strategic decision-making in real-world business contexts.
Conclusion
This Final Year Project demonstrates how quantitative data and visualization techniques can be used to analyze industry trends and business strategies. The insights gained from this project emphasize the importance of thoughtful interpretation of data rather than relying solely on surface-level metrics.
